articles.title: Definitions
articles.text:
For the purposes of this Regulation, the following definitions apply:

'digital operational resilience' means the ability of a financial entity to build, assure and review its operational integrity and reliability by ensuring, either directly or indirectly through the use of services provided by ICT third-party service providers, the full range of ICT-related capabilities needed to address the security of the network and information systems which a financial entity uses, and which support the continued provision of financial services and their quality.

'ICT risk' means any reasonably identifiable circumstance in relation to the use of network and information systems, which, if materialised, may compromise the security of the network and information systems, of any technology-dependent tool or process, of operations and processes, or of the provision of services, by producing adverse effects in the digital or physical environment.

'ICT-related incident' means an unplanned event or series of related events that compromises the security of the network and information systems, and has an adverse impact, or is likely to have an adverse impact, on the availability, authenticity, integrity or confidentiality of data.

'major ICT-related incident' means an ICT-related incident that has a high adverse impact on the network and information systems that support critical or important functions of the financial entity.

'significant cyber threat' means a cyber threat with the technical characteristics of a cyber threat that is likely to have severe impacts on the network and information systems of a financial entity.

'critical or important function' means a function whose disruption would materially impair the financial performance of a financial entity, or the soundness or continuity of its services and activities.

'ICT third-party service provider' means an undertaking providing digital and data services to one or more financial entities, including cloud computing service providers, software, data analytics services, data centres, and any other undertaking providing a digital service.

'critical ICT third-party service provider' means an ICT third-party service provider that has been designated as critical in accordance with Article 31.

'ICT services' means digital and data services provided through ICT systems to one or more internal or external users on an ongoing basis.

'ICT risk management framework' means the system of tools, methods, processes and policies addressing ICT risk.

'threat-led penetration testing' (TLPT) means a framework that mimics the tactics, techniques and procedures of real-life threat actors perceived as posing a genuine cyber threat, and delivers a controlled, bespoke, intelligence-led penetration test on the live production systems of the financial entity.

'concentration risk' means exposure to one or more ICT third-party service providers creating a degree of dependency on such providers so that unavailability, failure or other shortfall of that provider may endanger the ability of a financial entity to deliver critical or important functions.

articles.title: Proportionality Principle
articles.text:
1. Financial entities shall implement the rules laid down in Chapter II in accordance with the principle of proportionality, taking into account their size and overall risk profile, and the nature, scale and complexity of their services, activities and operations.

2. In addition, the application by financial entities of Chapters III, IV and V shall be proportionate to their size and overall risk profile, and the nature, scale and complexity of their services, activities and operations, as specifically required under the relevant provisions of those Chapters.

3. The competent authorities shall take into account the principle of proportionality when assessing the ICT risk management framework of financial entities on the basis of the reports submitted pursuant to Article 19(1).

4. The ESAs shall develop, through the Joint Committee, draft regulatory technical standards to further specify the elements, the criteria and where applicable the thresholds referred to in this Regulation, having due regard to the size and overall risk profile of financial entities, and the nature, scale and complexity of their activities.

Apply incident reporting proportionately based on nature, scale and complexity of activities

articles.title: ICT Risk Management Framework
articles.text:
1. Financial entities shall have a sound, comprehensive and well-documented ICT risk management framework as part of their overall risk management system.

2. The framework must include strategies, policies, procedures, ICT protocols and tools protecting information assets, computer software, hardware, servers, physical components, premises, data centres and sensitive areas from risks including damage and unauthorized access.

3. Entities shall minimize ICT risk impact through appropriate strategies, policies, procedures, ICT protocols and tools, providing complete and updated information to competent authorities upon request.

4. Non-microenterprise entities must assign ICT risk management responsibility to a control function with appropriate independence, ensuring proper segregation across the three lines of defence model.

5. The framework requires documented annual reviews (periodic for microenterprises), triggered by major incidents, supervisory instructions, or testing processes, with improvement based on implementation lessons and competent authority reporting.

6. Non-microenterprise frameworks undergo regular internal audits by auditors possessing sufficient knowledge, skills and expertise in ICT risk with appropriate independence, with audit frequency matching the entity's ICT risk level.

7. Entities must establish formal follow-up processes including timely verification and remediation of critical ICT audit findings.

8. The digital operational resilience strategy addresses ICT risk through eight specific points: (a) business alignment; (b) risk tolerance and impact analysis; (c) security objectives with key performance indicators; (d) ICT reference architecture; (e) incident detection mechanisms; (f) resilience documentation; (g) compliance testing; (h) incident communication strategy.

9. Entities may define holistic multi-vendor ICT strategies showing dependencies on third-party service providers.

10. Entities may outsource compliance verification to intra-group or external undertakings while retaining full responsibility for ICT risk management compliance.

articles.title: Identification
articles.text:
1. As part of the ICT risk management framework referred to in Article 6(1), financial entities shall identify, classify and adequately document all ICT supported business functions, roles and responsibilities, the information assets and ICT assets, including those located remotely, network resources and hardware equipment, and map those considered critical.

2. Financial entities shall identify all sources of ICT risk, in particular the risk exposure to and from other financial entities, and assess relevant cyber threats and ICT vulnerabilities with respect to the business functions, information assets and ICT assets. Financial entities shall review on a regular basis, and at least yearly, the risk scenarios impacting them.

3. Financial entities, other than microenterprises, shall perform a risk assessment upon each major change in the network and information system infrastructure, in the processes or procedures affecting their business functions, information assets or ICT assets.

4. Financial entities shall identify all information assets and ICT assets, including those with third-party service providers, and map the information assets considered critical. They shall update this mapping regularly and whenever there are major changes to the infrastructure.

5. Financial entities shall maintain and regularly update an inventory of all ICT assets and review ICT risks associated with each ICT asset identified in the inventory.

articles.title: Detection
articles.text:
1. Financial entities shall have in place mechanisms to promptly detect anomalous activities, in accordance with Article 17, including ICT network performance issues and ICT-related incidents, and to identify potential material single points of failure. Detection mechanisms must be regularly tested in accordance with Article 25.

2. Detection mechanisms should enable multiple layers of control, define alert thresholds and criteria to trigger and initiate ICT-related incident response processes, including automatic alert mechanisms for relevant staff in charge of ICT-related incident response.

3. Financial entities shall devote sufficient resources and capabilities to monitor user activity, the occurrence of ICT anomalies and ICT-related incidents, in particular cyber-attacks.

4. Data reporting service providers shall, in addition, have in place systems that can effectively check trade reports for completeness, identify omissions and obvious errors, and request re-transmission of those reports.

articles.title: Response and Recovery
articles.text:
1. Financial entities shall put in place a comprehensive ICT business continuity policy.

2. Entities must implement policies addressing:
(a) ensuring the continuity of the financial entity's critical or important functions;
(b) respond to and resolve ICT-related incidents in a way that limits damage;
(c) activate, without delay, dedicated plans that enable containment measures;
(d) estimate preliminary impacts, damages and losses;
(e) communication ensuring updated information is transmitted to all relevant internal staff.

3. Financial entities must implement associated ICT response and recovery plans.

4. Entities shall maintain and periodically test appropriate ICT business continuity plans, and ICT response and recovery plans.

5. Conduct business impact analysis assessing potential impact of severe business disruptions by means of quantitative and qualitative criteria, including through scenario analyses.

6. Test digital operational resilience plans at least once a year for non-microenterprises, and in the event of any substantive changes to ICT systems supporting critical or important functions.

7. Non-microenterprises shall require a crisis management function, establishing communication and crisis management procedures.

8. Keep readily accessible records of activities before and during disruption events.

9-11. ESAs shall develop guidelines on combined ICT business continuity policy and response and recovery plans for ICT-related incidents.

articles.title: Backup Policies and Procedures, Restoration and Recovery Procedures and Methods
articles.text:
1. For the purposes of ensuring the restoration of ICT systems and data with minimum downtime, limited disruption and loss, as part of their ICT risk management framework, financial entities shall develop and document:

(a) backup policies and procedures specifying the scope of the data that is subject to the backup and the minimum frequency of the backup, based on the criticality of information or the degree of confidentiality of the data;
(b) restoration and recovery procedures and methods.

2. Financial entities shall set up backup systems that can be activated in accordance with the backup policies and procedures and the restoration and recovery procedures and methods. The activation of backup systems shall not endanger the security of the network and information systems or the availability, authenticity, integrity or confidentiality of data. Testing of the backup procedures and restoration and recovery procedures and methods shall be undertaken periodically.

3. When restoring backup data using own systems, financial entities shall use ICT systems that are physically and logically segregated from the source ICT system. The ICT systems must be securely protected from any unauthorized access or ICT corruption and allow for the timely restoration of services making use of data and system backups as necessary.

4. Financial entities shall have in place appropriate multi-site resource configurations with sufficient capacity and capability to ensure business requirements. In the event of the unavailability of the primary ICT infrastructure, alternative ICT facilities, including at secondary sites, shall provide services with a level of service consistent with the financial entity's recovery time objectives and recovery point objectives.

5. Financial entities shall establish recovery time objectives and recovery point objectives for each business function and determine the level of resources and the total recovery time allocated to each business function, taking into account business impact analyses and the financial entity's overall risk tolerance and risk appetite.

6. Financial entities, other than microenterprises, shall report to the relevant competent authorities, upon their request, an estimation of aggregate annual costs and losses caused by major ICT-related incidents.

articles.title: Learning and Evolving
articles.text:
1. Financial entities shall have in place capabilities and staff to gather information on vulnerabilities and cyber threats, ICT-related incidents, in particular cyber-attacks, and analyse the impact they are likely to have on their digital operational resilience.

2. Financial entities shall put in place post-ICT-related incident reviews after a major ICT-related incident disrupts their core activities. Those reviews shall analyse the causes of disruption and identify required improvements to the ICT operations or within the ICT business continuity policy referred to in Article 11.

3. Financial entities, other than microenterprises, shall monitor effective implementation of the improvement measures referred to in paragraph 2 and shall also monitor, on an ongoing basis, the technological developments relevant to their business activities and operations.

4. Financial entities shall set up ICT security awareness programmes and digital operational resilience training as part of the staff training schemes. Those programmes and training shall be applicable to all staff and to senior management and shall have a level of complexity commensurate to the remit of their functions.

5. Financial entities, other than microenterprises, shall monitor relevant ICT third-party dependencies, keep track of evolving threats to their arrangements with ICT third-party service providers and review regularly their exposure to operational risk related to ICT third-party service providers.

6. Financial entities, other than microenterprises, shall report to the relevant competent authorities, on request, information about the number of major ICT-related incidents reported by ICT third-party service providers as part of the contractual arrangements.

articles.title: Communication
articles.text:
1. As part of the ICT risk management framework referred to in Article 6(1), financial entities shall have in place crisis communication plans enabling a responsible disclosure of, at least, major ICT-related incidents or significant cyber threats to clients and counterparts as well as to the public, as appropriate.

2. As part of the ICT risk management framework, financial entities shall implement communication policies for internal staff and for external stakeholders. Communication policies for staff shall address the need to make aware all relevant staff, including the management body, of at least all major ICT-related incidents, cyber threats and countermeasures adopted, as well as of the ICT risk management framework requirements.

3. At least one person shall be tasked with implementing the communication strategy for ICT-related incidents and fulfilling the public and media relation function for that purpose.

4. The communication obligations set out in this Article shall not result in the disclosure of confidential information or classified information or in the contravention of any applicable law.

articles.title: Classification of ICT-related Incidents and Cyber Threats
articles.text:
1. Financial entities shall classify ICT-related incidents and shall determine their impact based on the following criteria: the number of clients or financial counterparts affected and, where applicable, the amount or number of transactions affected by the major ICT-related incident; the duration of the major ICT-related incident, including the service downtime; the geographical spread with regard to the areas affected by the major ICT-related incident, particularly if it affects more than two Member States; the data losses that the major ICT-related incident entails, in relation to availability, authenticity, integrity or confidentiality of data; the criticality of the services affected, including the financial entity's transactions and operations; the economic impact, in particular direct and indirect costs and losses, of the major ICT-related incident, in both absolute and relative terms.

2. Entities shall classify cyber threats as significant based on the criticality of the services at risk, including the financial entity's transactions and operations, number and/or relevance of clients or financial counterparts targeted and the geographical spread of the areas at risk.

3. The ESAs shall develop regulatory technical standards specifying materiality thresholds and criteria for classification. The ESAs must submit these standards to the Commission by January 17, 2024.

articles.title: Reporting of major ICT-related incidents and voluntary notification of significant cyber threats
articles.text:
1. Financial entities shall report major ICT-related incidents to the relevant competent authority as referred to in Article 46 in accordance with paragraph 4 of this Article. Where a financial entity is subject to supervision by more than one national competent authority, Member States shall designate a single competent authority as the relevant competent authority. Credit institutions classified as significant shall report to the relevant national competent authority, which shall immediately transmit the report to the ECB.

2. Financial entities may, on a voluntary basis, notify significant cyber threats to the relevant competent authority when they deem the threat to be of relevance to the financial system, service users or clients.

3. Where a major ICT-related incident occurs and has an impact on the financial interests of clients, financial entities shall, without undue delay as soon as they become aware of it, inform their clients about the major ICT-related incident and about the measures that have been taken to mitigate the adverse effects of such incident. In the case of a significant cyber threat, financial entities shall, where applicable, inform their clients that are potentially affected of any appropriate protection measures which the latter may consider taking.

4. Financial entities shall submit the following to the relevant competent authority:
(a) an initial notification;
(b) an intermediate report after the initial notification, as soon as the status of the original incident has changed significantly, followed by updated notifications every time a relevant status update is available;
(c) a final report, when the root cause analysis has been completed and the actual impact figures are available to replace estimates.

5. Financial entities may outsource the reporting obligations under this Article to a third-party service provider. In case of such outsourcing, the financial entity remains fully responsible for the fulfilment of the incident reporting requirements.

articles.title: Centralised Reporting
articles.text:
1. The ESAs shall, through the Joint Committee, prepare a joint report assessing the feasibility of further centralisation of incident reporting through a single EU Hub for major ICT-related incident reporting by financial entities. The joint report shall explore ways to facilitate the flow of major ICT-related incident reports, reduce duplication of reporting requirements, and examine the synergies with the NIS 2 Directive reporting framework.

2. On the basis of that joint report, the Commission shall submit a report to the European Parliament and the Council, accompanied, where appropriate, by a legislative proposal.

3. Where such a legislative proposal is adopted, all financial entities shall submit major ICT-related incident reports to a designated single EU Hub. The single EU Hub shall relay the reports to the relevant national competent authorities, to ENISA, to Europol's European Cybercrime Centre and to any other entity depending on the competences of the authority that has received the report.

Financial entities should monitor and be prepared to adapt their incident reporting processes if a centralised EU Hub is established, as the single point of entry would replace direct reporting to national competent authorities for major ICT incidents.

articles.title: Operational or Security Payment-related Incidents
articles.text:
1. The requirements on major ICT-related incident reporting set out in Articles 19 and 20 shall also apply to major operational or security payment-related incidents where a financial entity, other than those referred to in point (c) of Article 2(1), is subject to the requirements of Directive (EU) 2015/2366.

2. Competent authorities shall inform EBA of payment incident reports received under Directive (EU) 2015/2366 and forward those reports to EBA on a timely basis, unless such reports would not be considered major under Article 19.

3. To the extent that the content of payment incident reports fulfils the requirements of the reporting obligations under this Article, financial entities may satisfy the requirements of this Article by submitting their payment incident reports. Duplication of reporting is not required where major operational or security payment-related incidents meet the criteria of major ICT-related incidents.

4. Financial entities subject to payment services regulations must align their operational or security incident reporting with DORA requirements to avoid duplicative reporting obligations. A single report satisfying both DORA and payment services directive requirements is acceptable where criteria are met.

articles.title: Digital Operational Resilience Testing
articles.text:
1. Financial entities, excluding microenterprises, shall maintain a sound and comprehensive digital operational resilience testing programme integrated into their ICT risk-management framework.

2. The testing programme shall encompass a range of assessments, tests, methodologies, practices and tools as set out in Articles 25 and 26.

3. The programme shall apply a risk-based approach considering the evolving landscape of ICT risk and any specific exposures of the financial entity.

4. Tests shall be undertaken by independent parties, whether internal or external. Where internal testers conduct tests, financial entities shall dedicate sufficient resources and ensure that conflicts of interest are avoided throughout the design and execution phases of the test.

5. Financial entities shall establish procedures and policies to prioritise, classify and remedy all issues revealed through the performance of the tests and shall establish internal validation methodologies to ascertain that all identified weaknesses, deficiencies or gaps are fully addressed.

6. Financial entities shall ensure that at least yearly, appropriate tests are conducted on all ICT systems and applications supporting critical or important functions.

articles.title: Testing of ICT Tools and Systems
articles.text:
1. The digital operational resilience testing programme referred to in Article 24 shall provide for the execution of appropriate tests, such as vulnerability assessments and scans, open source analyses, network security assessments, gap analyses, physical security reviews, questionnaires and scanning software solutions, source code reviews where feasible, scenario-based tests, compatibility testing, performance testing, end-to-end testing and penetration testing.

2. Central securities depositories and central counterparties shall perform vulnerability assessments before any deployment or redeployment of new or existing applications and infrastructure components, and ICT services supporting critical or important functions of the financial entity.

3. Microenterprises shall perform the tests referred to in paragraph 1 by combining a risk-based approach with a strategic planning of ICT testing, by duly considering the need to maintain a balanced approach between the scale of resources and the time to be allocated to the ICT testing, on the one hand, and the urgency, type of risk, criticality of information assets and of services provided, as well as any other relevant factor, on the other hand.
