articles.title: Advanced Testing of ICT Tools, Systems and Processes Based on Threat-Led Penetration Testing
articles.text:
1. Financial entities, other than microenterprises, that are identified by competent authorities as required to perform threat-led penetration testing (TLPT) shall carry out such testing at least every 3 years. Based on the risk profile of the financial entity and taking into account operational circumstances, the competent authority may where necessary request the financial entity to reduce or increase this frequency.

2. Each threat-led penetration test shall cover several or all critical or important functions of a financial entity and shall be performed on live production systems supporting such functions.

3. Financial entities shall identify all relevant underlying ICT systems, processes and technologies supporting critical or important functions and ICT services, including those outsourced or contracted to ICT third-party service providers, and, taking into account the fact that the financial entity remains fully responsible for ensuring compliance with this Article, shall coordinate with ICT third-party service providers to ensure their participation.

4. Threat-led penetration testing shall cover at minimum the following network perimeters: data flows in and out of network perimeters; network segmentation; and the security of third party services.

5. Financial entities shall use the threat intelligence to:
(a) determine the threat actors and their specific attack scenarios;
(b) define the scope of the TLPT;
(c) test against realistic and credible attack scenarios.

6. Pooled testing may be performed by multiple financial entities where an ICT third-party service provider provides material ICT services to multiple financial entities, subject to regulatory agreement and coordination by the lead overseer.

7. Upon completion of the TLPT, the financial entity and any ICT third-party service provider involved shall address all identified risks and remediate vulnerabilities discovered through the TLPT. The financial entity shall share the findings of the TLPT with the relevant competent authority.

8. Financial entities shall ensure the ICT third-party service providers' participation in TLPT activities in the contractual arrangements with those providers.
obligations: Conduct threat-led penetration testing (TLPT) at least every 3 years when required by competent authority
Cover several or all critical or important functions in each TLPT
Perform TLPT on live production systems
Identify all relevant ICT systems, processes and technologies supporting critical or important functions
Coordinate with ICT third-party service providers to ensure their participation in TLPT
Cover minimum network perimeters: data flows, network segmentation, third-party service security
Use threat intelligence to determine threat actors, attack scenarios and TLPT scope
Test against realistic and credible attack scenarios
Address all identified risks and remediate vulnerabilities after TLPT completion
Share TLPT findings with relevant competent authority
Ensure ICT third-party provider TLPT participation in contractual arrangements

articles.title: Requirements for Testers for the Carrying out of Threat-Led Penetration Testing
obligations: Use only testers of highest suitability and repute for TLPT
Ensure testers possess technical capabilities in threat intelligence, penetration testing and red team operations
Use certified or formally accredited testers adhering to recognised codes of conduct
Ensure testers provide independent assurance on sound management of TLPT risks
Ensure testers are covered by relevant professional indemnity insurance
Obtain competent authority approval when using internal testers for TLPT
Verify internal testers have dedicated resources and no conflicts of interest
Ensure threat intelligence provider is external when using internal testers
Verify tester compliance with requirements throughout TLPT duration
Perform appropriate due diligence when selecting TLPT testers

articles.title: General Principles — ICT Third-Party Risk Management
obligations: Manage ICT third-party risk within ICT risk management framework
Remain fully responsible for compliance with DORA despite third-party arrangements
Implement third-party risk management with proportionality principle
Adopt and regularly review ICT third-party risk strategy
Establish policy on ICT services supporting critical or important functions
Maintain register of all contractual arrangements at entity, sub-consolidated and consolidated levels
Report register yearly to competent authorities
Assess whether services support critical or important function before contracting
Verify supervisory conditions are met before contracting
Identify and assess all relevant risks including concentration risk
Conduct due diligence on prospective ICT third-party providers
Identify and assess conflicts of interest
Require ICT third-party providers to comply with appropriate information security standards
Consider most up-to-date information security standards for critical/important function providers
Determine audit frequency based on risk-based approach
Use commonly accepted audit standards for third-party assessments
Establish termination rights for significant breaches
Establish termination rights for performance-altering circumstances
Establish termination rights for ICT risk weaknesses
Establish termination rights for supervisory impediments
Develop exit strategies for orderly termination for critical or important functions

articles.title: Preliminary Assessment of ICT Concentration Risk
articles.text:
1. When performing the identification and assessment of risks referred to in Article 28(4)(c), financial entities shall also determine whether the conclusion of a contractual arrangement for ICT services supporting critical or important functions would lead to:

(a) contracting an ICT third-party service provider that is not easily substitutable;
(b) having in place multiple contractual arrangements in relation to the provision of ICT services supporting critical or important functions with the same ICT third-party service provider or with closely connected ICT third-party service providers.

Financial entities shall weigh the benefits and costs of alternative solutions, such as the use of different ICT third-party service providers, taking into account whether and how envisaged solutions match the business needs and objectives set out in the digital operational resilience strategy.

2. Where the contractual arrangements on the use of ICT services include the possibility that an ICT third-party service provider further subcontracts ICT services supporting a critical or important function to other ICT third-party service providers, financial entities shall weigh benefits and risks that may arise in connection with such subcontracting, in particular with regard to a third-country ICT subcontractor.

Where contractual arrangements concern ICT services supporting critical or important functions, financial entities shall duly consider the insolvency law provisions that would apply in the event of the ICT third-party service provider's bankruptcy as well as any constraint that may arise in respect of the urgent recovery of the financial entity's data.

Where contractual arrangements on the use of ICT services are concluded with an ICT third-party service provider established in a third country, financial entities shall additionally consider compliance with Union data protection rules and the effective enforcement of the law in that third country.

Where the subcontracting is permitted, financial entities shall evaluate whether and how potentially long or complex chains of subcontracting may impact their ability to fully monitor the contracted functions and the ability of the competent authority to effectively supervise the financial entity in that respect.
obligations: Assess concentration risk before concluding critical or important function service arrangements
Evaluate substitutability of proposed third-party provider
Assess multiple-arrangement risk with same or closely connected providers
Weigh benefits and costs of alternative solutions
Align third-party arrangements with digital operational resilience strategy
Assess risks of permitted subcontracting for critical or important functions
Evaluate third-country subcontractor risks
Consider insolvency law provisions applicable to the provider
Assess constraints affecting urgent data recovery
Assess third-country provider compliance with Union data protection rules
Assess effective enforcement of law in third country
Evaluate impact of complex subcontracting chains on monitoring ability

articles.title: Key Contractual Provisions
obligations: Clearly allocate rights and obligations in writing
Document full contract including SLA in writing or accessible durable format
Provide clear and complete description of all functions and ICT services
Specify subcontracting permissions and applicable conditions
Specify locations of service provision and data processing
Require notification when provider changes locations
Include data availability, authenticity, integrity and confidentiality protection provisions
Include provisions for data access, recovery and return upon insolvency or termination
Include service level descriptions including updates and revisions
Require provider assistance at no additional cost upon ICT incident
Require full cooperation with competent authorities and resolution authorities
Include termination rights and minimum notice periods
Include conditions for participation in ICT security awareness programmes
Include precise quantitative and qualitative performance targets for critical/important functions
Include notice periods and reporting obligations for material impact developments
Require provider to implement and test business contingency plans
Require provider participation in TLPT per Articles 26 and 27
Include unrestricted rights of access, inspection and audit
Include exit strategies with mandatory adequate transition period
Transition period must allow continued service provision to reduce disruption risk
Transition period must allow migration to another provider or in-house solutions
Use standard contractual clauses developed by public authorities where available

articles.title: Designation of Critical ICT Third-Party Service Providers
articles.text:
1. The ESAs, through the Joint Committee, on the basis of a recommendation from the Joint Examination Team, shall designate ICT third-party service providers that are critical for financial entities.

2. The designation shall be based on criteria including: the systemic impact on the stability, continuity or quality of the provision of financial services of ICT third-party service providers' failure or disruption; the systemic character or importance of the financial entities that rely on the relevant ICT third-party service providers; the degree of substitutability of the ICT third-party service provider; the number of global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs) or other systemically important institutions (O-SIIs) that rely on the ICT third-party service provider; the interdependence between the ICT third-party service providers and the number of ICT third-party service providers that are interconnected with each other; and the innovation level or the degree of sophistication of the ICT services involved.

3. A designation as a critical ICT third-party service provider shall not be made where the ICT third-party service provider is:
(a) a financial entity under this Regulation;
(b) a financial entity or an ICT third-party service provider established in a third country where reciprocal oversight of ICT third-party service providers does not exist;
(c) an intra-group ICT service provider.

4. The ESAs shall maintain a public register of designated critical ICT third-party service providers.

Financial entities must identify which of their ICT third-party service providers are or become designated as critical, as this affects oversight requirements and enhances the scrutiny applied to those providers.
obligations: Identify which ICT third-party providers are designated as critical by ESAs
Monitor the ESA public register of designated critical ICT third-party service providers
Apply heightened oversight to contractual arrangements with critical ICT third-party service providers
Understand that critical ICT third-party service providers are subject to Lead Overseer supervision
Cooperate with Lead Overseer information requests regarding critical provider relationships
Notify competent authorities of material changes to arrangements with critical ICT third-party providers

articles.title: Structure of the Oversight Framework
articles.text:
1. The Joint Committee of the ESAs, assisted by the Oversight Forum, shall coordinate the Oversight Framework activities of the relevant ESAs and ensure consistent application.

2. Each critical ICT third-party service provider shall be assigned to one of the ESAs as a Lead Overseer based on which type of financial entities it primarily provides services to. The Lead Overseer for critical ICT third-party service providers primarily serving credit institutions and investment firms shall be the EBA. The Lead Overseer for critical ICT third-party service providers primarily serving insurance undertakings shall be EIOPA. The Lead Overseer for critical ICT third-party service providers primarily serving fund managers, CCPs, trading venues and trade repositories shall be ESMA.

3. The Oversight Forum shall be composed of the Chairpersons of the ESAs, high-level representatives from competent authorities, and the ECB. It shall, inter alia, prepare draft recommendations for Lead Overseers and facilitate coordination of national competent authorities regarding oversight of critical ICT third-party service providers.

4. Financial entities shall cooperate with the Lead Overseer and provide information requested by the Lead Overseer regarding their use of services from critical ICT third-party service providers.

5. The Lead Overseer shall have access to all relevant documents and information including those held by financial entities related to critical ICT third-party providers.
obligations: Cooperate with the Lead Overseer (EBA, EIOPA or ESMA depending on entity type) regarding critical ICT third-party providers
Provide information requested by Lead Overseer on use of critical ICT third-party services
Make documents and information available to Lead Overseer when requested
Understand that EBA oversees critical providers serving credit institutions and investment firms
Understand that EIOPA oversees critical providers serving insurance undertakings
Understand that ESMA oversees critical providers serving fund managers, CCPs, trading venues and trade repositories

articles.title: Tasks of the Lead Overseer
obligations: Support Lead Overseer tasks in supervising critical ICT third-party service providers
Ensure contractual arrangements with critical ICT providers allow Lead Overseer effective oversight
Include provisions in contracts enabling Lead Overseer access and inspection rights
Cooperate with general investigations and inspections of critical ICT third-party providers
Provide information to Lead Overseer as requested regarding critical ICT provider relationships

articles.title: Operational Coordination between Lead Overseers
articles.text:
1. Lead Overseers shall coordinate and cooperate, in particular through the Oversight Forum, when exercising their respective oversight mandates.

2. Lead Overseers shall share information related to critical ICT third-party service providers, including information on serious incidents and on oversight assessments.

3. National competent authorities shall cooperate with the Lead Overseer and share information with the Lead Overseer where such information is relevant to the oversight of the critical ICT third-party service providers.

4. Financial entities shall not be required to disclose the same information to multiple Lead Overseers where a critical ICT third-party service provider is subject to oversight by more than one Lead Overseer.

Financial entities should be aware of the coordination mechanisms between oversight authorities to avoid duplication and ensure consistency in responding to information requests related to their critical ICT third-party service providers.
obligations: Avoid duplicative information disclosures where critical provider is subject to multiple Lead Overseers
Cooperate with coordinated oversight activities across multiple Lead Overseers
Maintain records enabling coordinated oversight information requests to be fulfilled efficiently

articles.title: Powers of the Lead Overseer
articles.text:
1. For the purpose of fulfilling the mandate referred to in Article 33(2), the Lead Overseer shall have the following powers in relation to critical ICT third-party service providers:

(a) the power to request all relevant information and documentation pursuant to Article 37;
(b) the power to conduct general investigations and inspections pursuant to Articles 38 and 39;
(c) the power to request, after the completion of the oversight activities, reports specifying the actions taken or the remedies implemented by the critical ICT third-party service provider in relation to the recommendations of the Lead Overseer.

2. The Lead Overseer may also conduct oversight activities jointly with the competent authorities.

3. When exercising its powers, the Lead Overseer shall take into account the scale and complexity of the services provided by the critical ICT third-party service provider, and the nature, extent and complexity of the ICT services provided to financial entities.

4. The Lead Overseer shall impose periodic penalty payments to compel critical ICT third-party service providers to comply with requests for information, investigations, inspections, remediation actions and recommendations.

5. The periodic penalty payment for each day of non-compliance shall not exceed 1% of the average daily worldwide turnover of the critical ICT third-party service provider in the preceding business year.

6. The Lead Overseer may require, within a specified period, financial entities that use services from the critical ICT third-party service provider to terminate, in full or in part, the contractual arrangements with that provider.

Financial entities must cooperate with the Lead Overseer when exercising its powers and may be required to terminate arrangements with non-compliant critical ICT third-party service providers.
obligations: Cooperate with Lead Overseer investigations and information requests regarding critical ICT providers
Provide documentation requested by Lead Overseer about critical ICT provider relationships
Be prepared to terminate contractual arrangements with critical ICT providers upon Lead Overseer order
Cooperate with joint oversight activities conducted with competent authorities
Facilitate Lead Overseer access to conduct oversight activities effectively

articles.title: Exercise of the Powers of the Lead Overseer Outside the Union
articles.text:
1. Where an ICT third-party service provider that has been designated as critical is established in a third country, it shall establish a subsidiary in the Union within 12 months of its designation as a critical ICT third-party service provider.

2. The requirement referred to in paragraph 1 shall not apply where:
(a) the ICT third-party service provider is established in a country with which the Union has concluded an international agreement on the mutual recognition and equivalence of oversight regimes for ICT third-party service providers;
(b) the ICT third-party service provider can demonstrate that the oversight requirements applied in the third country in which it is established are equivalent to those of this Regulation;
(c) after the completion of the oversight activities, the Lead Overseer has concluded that the ICT third-party service provider is not subject to oversight arrangements in a third country.

3. Financial entities using services from third-country critical ICT third-party service providers shall monitor the status of Union subsidiary requirements and the compliance of their providers.

Financial entities contracting ICT services from providers in third countries should assess whether those providers may be designated as critical and what the implications are for their service arrangements and continuity.
obligations: Monitor compliance of critical third-country ICT providers with Union subsidiary establishment requirements
Assess implications of third-country provider designation as critical for service continuity
Consider third-country regulatory equivalence when evaluating ICT provider risk
Include provisions in contracts with third-country providers addressing oversight cooperation requirements
Plan for contingency if third-country critical ICT provider fails to establish EU subsidiary

articles.title: Request for Information
obligations: Assist the Lead Overseer in providing information about critical ICT third-party provider relationships where requested
Maintain comprehensive records of contractual arrangements with critical ICT third-party providers
Respond promptly and accurately to Lead Overseer requests for information
Ensure records include all relevant documents, contracts, policies and audit reports related to critical ICT providers
Ensure information provided to Lead Overseer is accurate, complete and not misleading

articles.title: General Investigations
obligations: Cooperate fully with Lead Overseer investigations of critical ICT third-party providers
Provide oral or written explanations to Lead Overseer investigators when requested
Provide supporting documentation or evidence during Lead Overseer investigations
Ensure contractual arrangements include provisions facilitating Lead Overseer investigation cooperation
Make records and data available to Lead Overseer investigators upon request

articles.title: Inspections
obligations: Facilitate Lead Overseer on-site inspections of critical ICT third-party service providers where required
Participate in Lead Overseer inspection activities when requested
Ensure contracts with critical ICT providers include Lead Overseer inspection access provisions
Ensure contracts include competent authority inspection access provisions
Cooperate with officials authorised to conduct inspections of critical ICT third-party providers

articles.title: Continuous Oversight
obligations: Monitor Lead Overseer oversight plan outcomes and recommendations for critical ICT providers
Adapt use of critical ICT providers based on Lead Overseer oversight findings
Monitor competent authority notifications regarding critical ICT provider non-compliance
Plan contingency responses to potential Lead Overseer non-compliance notifications regarding critical providers
Review contractual arrangements with critical ICT providers in light of oversight findings and recommendations

articles.title: Harmonisation of Conditions Enabling the Conduct of Oversight Activities
obligations: Comply with RTS requirements on facilitating information exchange with Lead Overseers during oversight activities
Implement processes to efficiently provide information to Lead Overseers in prescribed format and content
Monitor publication of regulatory technical standards governing oversight activity harmonisation
Update internal procedures when RTS requirements on oversight cooperation are published

articles.title: Follow-up by Competent Authorities
articles.text:
1. Without prejudice to the powers of competent authorities under relevant sectoral Union law, where the Lead Overseer has informed a competent authority that a critical ICT third-party service provider has failed to comply with the recommendations issued to it pursuant to Article 40(2), the competent authority shall, where the failure to comply with those recommendations is likely to affect the digital operational resilience of the financial entity using the ICT services of that critical ICT third-party service provider, take the following measures:

(a) direct the financial entity to temporarily suspend, in full or in part, the use of or reliance on the relevant ICT services until the risks identified in the recommendations have been addressed;
(b) direct the financial entity to terminate, in full or in part, the relevant contractual arrangements with the critical ICT third-party service provider.

2. Where a financial entity has been directed to terminate a contractual arrangement under paragraph 1, point (b), such termination shall take effect in accordance with the applicable terms and conditions of the contractual arrangement and in a manner that limits the disruption to the financial entity's operations.

3. Financial entities shall develop contingency plans and exit strategies to enable orderly termination of critical ICT service relationships when directed to do so by competent authorities.

4. Financial entities shall monitor the compliance status of their critical ICT third-party service providers with Lead Overseer recommendations.
obligations: Be prepared to suspend use of critical ICT services if directed by competent authority due to provider non-compliance
Be prepared to terminate critical ICT service contractual arrangements if directed by competent authority
Develop contingency plans enabling orderly termination of critical ICT service relationships
Maintain exit strategies for critical ICT third-party service providers
Monitor compliance of critical ICT providers with Lead Overseer recommendations
Ensure exit strategy allows termination without excessive disruption to operations

articles.title: Oversight Fees
articles.text:
1. The Lead Overseer shall charge annual supervisory fees to critical ICT third-party service providers. Those fees shall cover all expenses incurred by the Lead Overseer with respect to the supervision of critical ICT third-party service providers pursuant to this Regulation.

2. The total amount of annual supervisory fees charged to a specific critical ICT third-party service provider shall be proportionate to its size, measured by its annual net revenues received from the provision of ICT services to financial entities in the Union.

3. The ESAs shall develop, by means of delegated acts, the methodology for calculating the supervisory fees and the procedure for the payment of those fees.

Financial entities should be aware that their critical ICT third-party service providers may seek to recover oversight fees through pricing adjustments in service contracts. Financial entities should review existing and new contracts with critical ICT providers for provisions related to regulatory cost pass-through.
obligations: Review contractual arrangements with critical ICT providers for provisions related to regulatory oversight fee pass-through
Assess impact of oversight fees on total cost of critical ICT services
Ensure contracts address allocation of regulatory compliance costs including oversight fees
Monitor changes to oversight fee methodology that may affect critical ICT service pricing

articles.title: International Cooperation
articles.text:
1. The ESAs may, in accordance with Article 33 of Regulations (EU) No 1093/2010, No 1094/2010 and No 1095/2010, conclude administrative arrangements with third-country regulatory and supervisory authorities in order to foster international supervisory cooperation.

2. The ESAs shall share information received from third-country authorities with their respective Board of Supervisors and the Oversight Forum.

3. Financial entities subject to DORA and using ICT services from providers in third countries should be aware of international cooperation arrangements that may affect oversight of those providers and of the information that may be shared with third-country authorities.

4. Financial entities should assess the implications of international cooperation frameworks when engaging with ICT third-party service providers established in non-EU jurisdictions, including the potential sharing of information about the financial entity's use of ICT services with third-country regulatory authorities.
obligations: Be aware of international cooperation agreements affecting oversight of third-country ICT providers
Assess information-sharing implications when using ICT providers in non-EU jurisdictions
Review cross-border data handling and regulatory information sharing provisions in third-country ICT provider contracts
Monitor international cooperation developments that may affect oversight of critical ICT third-party providers

articles.title: Arrangements for Information Sharing
obligations: Participate in trusted community information-sharing arrangements on cyber threats where appropriate
Ensure information-sharing arrangements protect sensitive information and respect business confidentiality
Comply with GDPR requirements when sharing information in cyber threat intelligence arrangements
Designate senior management member responsible for information-sharing arrangement implementation and oversight
Report information-sharing arrangement developments to management body
Inform competent authorities of participation in information-sharing arrangements
Cooperate with competent authorities on matters related to information-sharing
Limit information sharing to aims of enhancing digital operational resilience
Ensure information-sharing operates within trusted communities of financial entities

articles.title: Designation of Competent Authorities
articles.text:
1. Without prejudice to the competence of the European Central Bank regarding specific supervisory tasks conferred on it pursuant to Council Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013, the supervision of compliance with this Regulation shall be carried out by the competent authorities designated in accordance with the relevant sector-specific Union legislation applicable to financial entities.

2. Each Member State shall designate one or more competent authorities responsible for supervising the application of this Regulation in respect of each category of financial entity listed in Article 2(1). Where a Member State designates more than one competent authority, it shall clearly delineate the respective tasks of those authorities and designate a single contact point for international cooperation and supervisory coordination purposes.

3. Financial entities shall identify their designated competent authority under this Regulation and maintain up-to-date records of all competent authorities with jurisdiction over their activities.

4. Competent authorities designated under this Article shall have all supervisory, investigatory and sanctioning powers necessary to fulfil their duties under this Regulation. Their powers shall be exercised in a proportionate and effective manner, having due regard to the size, systemic importance, nature, scale and complexity of the financial entity.
obligations: Identify and record the competent authority designated to supervise DORA compliance for your entity type and jurisdiction
Maintain up-to-date records of all competent authorities with jurisdiction over your activities
Cooperate fully with your designated competent authority on all DORA-related supervisory activities
Provide information and assistance to the single contact point for international cooperation when requested
Respond promptly to all supervisory enquiries from your designated competent authority

articles.title: Cooperation among Competent Authorities
articles.text:
1. Competent authorities shall cooperate closely with each other and, where relevant, with the Lead Overseers designated under Article 31, including by exchanging all information that is necessary for the purpose of carrying out their duties under this Regulation using their powers whether or not referred to in this Regulation.

2. Competent authorities shall, at least annually, provide the relevant ESAs with aggregated information on all administrative penalties and remedial measures imposed in accordance with this Regulation, indicating the type of breach and the nature of the administrative penalty or remedial measure imposed.

3. Financial entities shall cooperate with their competent authority in the facilitation of supervisory cooperation between authorities from different Member States or jurisdictions.

4. Where a financial entity operates in multiple Member States, competent authorities concerned shall exchange information and coordinate supervisory activities to ensure consistent application of this Regulation. Financial entities must designate a clear contact point for each relevant competent authority.
obligations: Cooperate with all competent authorities from Member States where you operate or provide services
Designate a clear internal contact point for each relevant competent authority
Facilitate information exchange between competent authorities when requested
Respond to supervisory requests from competent authorities from other Member States where relevant
Support cross-border supervisory coordination activities as required

articles.title: Cooperation with EBA, ESMA and EIOPA
articles.text:
1. The competent authorities designated pursuant to Article 46 shall cooperate closely with the European Banking Authority (EBA), the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) and the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) (together, the 'ESAs') on all matters relating to the application of this Regulation.

2. Without delay and on a voluntary basis, financial entities that detect a significant cyber threat shall notify the relevant competent authority thereof. The competent authority may in turn transmit information to relevant ESAs, Lead Overseers and relevant public authorities where warranted by the systemic nature of the threat.

3. Financial entities shall provide ESAs with all information required for the performance of their duties under this Regulation upon request.

4. ESAs shall develop common regulatory technical standards (RTS) and implementing technical standards (ITS) to give practical effect to DORA's requirements. Financial entities must comply with all RTS and ITS adopted pursuant to this Regulation.
obligations: Voluntarily and promptly notify competent authorities of significant cyber threats detected
Provide all information requested by ESAs (EBA, ESMA, EIOPA) for performance of their duties
Comply with all Regulatory Technical Standards (RTS) and Implementing Technical Standards (ITS) adopted under DORA
Monitor and implement ESA guidelines and recommendations relevant to your entity type
Support ESA supervisory convergence initiatives and respond to ESA information-gathering exercises

articles.title: Cooperation with Third-Country Authorities
articles.text:
1. Competent authorities may conclude administrative cooperation arrangements with supervisory authorities of third countries in the area of digital operational resilience, including information exchange and mutual assistance in supervisory activities.

2. Financial entities operating in both Member States and third countries shall facilitate the exchange of supervisory information between competent authorities and third-country supervisory authorities, to the extent permitted by applicable law and contractual arrangements.

3. Where relevant, competent authorities shall inform their counterpart third-country authorities of significant ICT incidents affecting financial entities operating in those countries. Financial entities shall cooperate with this cross-border information flow.

4. Financial entities that are subsidiaries of third-country groups shall ensure that group-level DORA compliance information is available to their Union competent authorities, even where the parent entity is established outside the Union.
obligations: Facilitate exchange of supervisory information between Union and third-country supervisory authorities when requested
Ensure group-level DORA compliance information is accessible to Union competent authorities for third-country group subsidiaries
Cooperate with cross-border information exchange on significant ICT incidents affecting multi-jurisdiction operations
Maintain records of cross-border ICT service dependencies that may be relevant to third-country supervisory cooperation
Ensure contractual arrangements with ICT providers support necessary cross-border supervisory disclosure

articles.title: Administrative Penalties and Remedial Measures
obligations: Provide competent authorities with access to all documents, data, procedures and materials in any format requested
Cooperate fully with on-site inspections and investigations at business premises
Ensure management body members and staff respond to competent authority requests for explanations
Implement all remedial measures within timeframes specified by the competent authority
Refrain from obstructing supervisory activities — obstruction constitutes a breach of DORA
Comply with interim measures ordered by competent authorities in cases of significant risk to financial stability
Cease any conduct determined by the competent authority to be in breach of this Regulation

articles.title: Administrative Penalties
obligations: Maintain full compliance with ICT risk management requirements to avoid penalties of up to EUR 10,000,000 or 2% of global annual turnover
Ensure management individuals are aware of personal liability of up to EUR 5,000,000 for DORA breaches
Demonstrate cooperation with competent authority as a mitigating factor in any penalty proceedings
Adopt and document remedial measures promptly to reduce penalty exposure
Maintain records demonstrating compliance efforts to support proportionality arguments in enforcement proceedings
Ensure board-level awareness of DORA penalty regime and financial exposure

articles.title: Criminal Sanctions
articles.text:
1. Where Member States have decided, in accordance with national law, to lay down criminal sanctions for breaches of provisions that are subject to administrative penalties under this Regulation, they shall ensure that appropriate measures are in place so that competent authorities have all necessary powers to liaise with judicial, prosecuting or criminal justice authorities within their jurisdiction to receive specific information related to criminal investigations or proceedings commenced for breaches of this Regulation.

2. Natural persons responsible for DORA breaches within financial entities may face both criminal sanctions (where provided by national law) and administrative penalties, without prejudice to the non bis in idem principle.

3. Financial entities shall maintain internal governance frameworks that attribute clear individual responsibility for DORA compliance, enabling identification of responsible natural persons in enforcement proceedings.

4. Competent authorities shall cooperate with criminal justice authorities where criminal proceedings arise from DORA breaches. Financial entities shall cooperate with both regulatory and criminal investigations.
obligations: Maintain internal governance frameworks that clearly attribute individual responsibility for DORA compliance obligations
Ensure senior management and board members are personally aware of potential criminal liability for DORA breaches under national law
Cooperate with criminal justice authorities in any investigation related to DORA breaches
Implement documented escalation procedures ensuring rapid disclosure of potential DORA breaches to board level
Maintain records demonstrating personal compliance oversight by responsible individuals
Ensure legal counsel is engaged to assess national criminal sanction provisions applicable to DORA breaches

articles.title: RTS on ICT Risk Management — Asset Management, Change Control and Cryptography
articles.text:
Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2024/1774 (13 March 2024) provides detailed technical requirements implementing DORA Articles 5–16. Key provisions:

1. ICT Asset Management: Financial entities must maintain a complete, continuously updated inventory of all ICT assets (hardware, software, data repositories, network components, cloud resources, and mobile devices). Each asset must record its owner, classification, location, and interdependencies. Assets supporting critical or important functions must be tagged and subject to enhanced controls.

2. Change Management: All ICT changes (upgrades, patches, configuration modifications) must follow a documented change management procedure encompassing: change request, risk assessment, approval by authorised personnel, testing in a non-production environment, rollback plan, and post-change validation. Emergency changes require retrospective documentation.

3. Encryption and Key Management: Data at rest and in transit supporting critical or important functions must be encrypted using current cryptographic standards. Financial entities must maintain a documented key management policy covering key generation, distribution, storage, rotation, revocation, and destruction. Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) are recommended for high-assurance key storage.

4. Endpoint and Network Security: Entities must deploy and maintain endpoint detection and response (EDR) solutions, network access control, intrusion detection and prevention systems (IDS/IPS), and network segmentation using firewalls and DMZ architectures. All external-facing interfaces must be protected by web application firewalls (WAF) or equivalent controls.

5. Vulnerability Management: A formal vulnerability and patch management programme must define SLA targets: critical vulnerabilities (CVSS ≥9.0) remediated within 1 month, high (CVSS 7.0–8.9) within 3 months, medium within 6 months. Regular vulnerability scanning (minimum quarterly for internet-facing systems) and penetration testing are required.
obligations: Maintain a continuously updated ICT asset inventory covering all hardware, software, data, networks, cloud and mobile assets
Classify all ICT assets and apply enhanced controls for those supporting critical or important functions
Implement a documented change management procedure including risk assessment, non-production testing, approval, rollback plan and post-change validation
Encrypt all data at rest and in transit for critical or important functions using current cryptographic standards
Maintain a documented cryptographic key management policy covering generation, distribution, storage, rotation, revocation and destruction
Deploy endpoint detection and response (EDR), network access control, IDS/IPS, and network segmentation controls
Protect all external-facing interfaces with WAF or equivalent controls
Define and enforce patching SLAs: critical (CVSS ≥9.0) within 1 month, high within 3 months, medium within 6 months
Conduct minimum quarterly vulnerability scanning on internet-facing systems
Document all ICT security policies and review them at least annually

articles.title: RTS on Classification of ICT-related Incidents — Major Incident Thresholds
articles.text:
Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2024/1772 specifies the classification criteria for determining whether an ICT-related incident must be reported to competent authorities as a 'major ICT-related incident' under DORA Article 18. An incident is major if it meets one or more of the following threshold criteria:

1. Clients affected: The incident directly affects more than 10% of the financial entity's total client base, or more than 1,000 clients, whichever is lower.

2. Service unavailability: The incident causes service disruption for critical or important functions lasting more than 4 consecutive hours, or causes repeated interruptions totalling more than 4 hours in a 24-hour period.

3. Data breach impact: The incident results in the loss, corruption or unavailability of data representing more than 0.1% of the financial entity's total client records, or more than 1,000 individual client records, whichever is lower.

4. Reputational damage: The incident results in significant media coverage or triggers a formal enquiry from a competent authority or law enforcement body.

5. Geographic spread: The incident affects ICT infrastructure or services in more than two Member States simultaneously.

6. Financial impact: The incident causes direct financial losses exceeding EUR 1,000,000 or equivalent in other currencies.

7. Systemic risk: The incident, even if below the quantitative thresholds, has the potential to propagate to other financial entities or to financial market infrastructure.

Financial entities must assess incidents against all seven criteria at the time of initial detection and at each subsequent review point.
obligations: Assess every ICT-related incident against all seven major incident classification criteria within the initial detection period
Classify as major if more than 10% of clients or more than 1,000 clients are affected
Classify as major if service disruption to critical functions exceeds 4 consecutive hours
Classify as major if data breach affects more than 0.1% of client records or more than 1,000 records
Classify as major if the incident receives significant media coverage or triggers regulatory enquiry
Classify as major if the incident affects infrastructure in more than two Member States
Classify as major if direct financial losses exceed EUR 1,000,000
Assess systemic risk potential even when quantitative thresholds are not met
Re-assess incident classification at each review point as new information becomes available
Document the classification rationale for every ICT incident regardless of whether it is major

articles.title: ITS on Major Incident Reporting — Templates, Timelines and Content
articles.text:
The Implementing Technical Standards on reporting templates and timelines (adopted under DORA Article 20) establish the following mandatory reporting obligations for major ICT-related incidents:

1. Initial Notification (within 4 hours of classification as major): Financial entities must submit an initial notification to their competent authority containing: incident identifier, date and time of detection and classification, preliminary description of the incident, affected business lines and geographic scope, estimated number of clients affected, preliminary assessment of financial impact, and immediate containment measures applied. The 4-hour deadline runs from the moment the incident is classified as major, not from initial detection.

2. Intermediate Report (within 72 hours of initial notification): The intermediate report must include: updated assessment of incident scope and impact, root cause analysis if available, containment and recovery measures implemented, revised estimate of client and financial impact, business continuity measures activated, and current status of the incident.

3. Final Report (within 1 month of incident resolution): The final report must include: complete root cause analysis, full timeline from detection to resolution, total number of clients affected, total direct and indirect financial losses, all corrective and preventive measures implemented or planned, lessons learned, and a forward-looking resilience improvement plan.

4. Voluntary Notification: Financial entities may voluntarily notify competent authorities of significant cyber threats that have not yet caused an incident but that could escalate. Voluntary notifications should follow the initial notification format.

5. Reporting to clients: Financial entities must notify affected clients of major ICT incidents without undue delay and in a clear, non-technical manner.
obligations: Submit initial notification to competent authority within 4 hours of classifying an incident as major
Include incident ID, timeline, preliminary description, affected business lines, and client impact estimate in the initial notification
Submit an intermediate report within 72 hours of the initial notification with updated scope, root cause analysis and recovery measures
Submit a final report within 1 month of incident resolution including full root cause analysis, financial impact, and lessons learned
Maintain an incident register with unique identifiers for all ICT-related incidents regardless of classification
Report voluntarily on significant cyber threats that have not yet caused an incident using the initial notification format
Notify affected clients without undue delay and in plain language when a major ICT incident affects their services
Ensure all three report types (initial, intermediate, final) use the competent authority's prescribed templates

articles.title: RTS on Threat-Led Penetration Testing (TLPT) — Requirements and Methodology
articles.text:
The Joint Committee Final Report JC 2023 86 (RTS on TLPT under DORA Article 26) establishes requirements for Threat-Led Penetration Testing based on the TIBER-EU framework. Key provisions:

1. Scope of application: TLPT applies to financial entities identified by competent authorities as significant based on their systemic importance, interconnectedness, and complexity. Competent authorities identify in-scope entities at least every 3 years.

2. Testing frequency: In-scope financial entities must conduct TLPT at least every 3 years on systems, applications and infrastructure supporting critical or important functions.

3. Methodology: TLPT must follow a three-phase approach: (a) Threat Intelligence phase — commissioned from an approved Threat Intelligence provider, produces a Targeted Threat Intelligence report identifying the most likely attack scenarios; (b) Red Team phase — a certified red team provider executes realistic attack simulations based on the threat intelligence, targeting live production systems; (c) Closure phase — findings are validated with the blue team, remediation plans documented, and a formal test report produced.

4. Tester requirements: Red team providers must be certified by the competent authority or a recognised certification body. Internal red teams may be used if they meet independence requirements.

5. Pooled testing: Where multiple financial entities share the same ICT infrastructure or service providers, competent authorities may authorise joint TLPT exercises.

6. ICT third-party participation: ICT third-party service providers supporting critical or important functions may be required to participate in and support TLPT exercises.

7. Remediation: Financial entities must produce a documented remediation plan addressing all TLPT findings within 3 months of test completion and report progress to the competent authority.
obligations: Determine whether your entity is in scope for TLPT based on competent authority designation criteria
Conduct TLPT at least every 3 years if designated as in-scope by the competent authority
Commission Targeted Threat Intelligence from an approved provider before commencing red team testing
Engage a certified red team provider to conduct realistic attack simulations on live production systems
Ensure TLPT covers all systems, applications and infrastructure supporting critical or important functions
Require ICT third-party service providers supporting critical functions to participate in and support TLPT exercises
Produce a documented remediation plan addressing all TLPT findings within 3 months of test completion
Report TLPT results and remediation progress to the competent authority in prescribed format
Retain all TLPT documentation (threat intelligence, red team report, remediation plan) for at least 5 years
Consider pooled TLPT arrangements where shared ICT infrastructure is used across financial entities

articles.title: RTS on ICT Third-Party Risk — Due Diligence, Assessment and Oversight
articles.text:
The EBA Final Report EBA/RTS/2024/05 on RTS on ICT third-party risk establishes detailed requirements for the assessment, management and ongoing oversight of ICT third-party service providers under DORA Articles 28–30. Key provisions:

1. Pre-contracting due diligence: Before entering any ICT arrangement supporting critical or important functions, financial entities must conduct a documented risk assessment covering: the provider's ICT security posture and certifications (ISO 27001, SOC 2 Type II), business continuity and disaster recovery capabilities (RTO/RPO commitments, DR test results), subcontracting chain and data processing locations, financial stability and operational resilience track record, regulatory standing and any enforcement actions in the past 5 years, and reference checks with other financial entity clients.

2. Proportionate assessment: The depth of due diligence must be proportionate to the criticality of the function. Providers supporting critical or important functions require enhanced due diligence; standard functions require lighter-touch assessment.

3. Concentration risk assessment (Article 29): Before contracting with a provider already serving multiple financial entities, the financial entity must assess: the provider's overall market share in the relevant service category, the number and systemic importance of other financial entity clients, geographic concentration of infrastructure, and the entity's ability to substitute the provider within an acceptable timeframe.

4. Ongoing monitoring: ICT third-party service providers supporting critical or important functions must be subject to: annual formal performance and security reviews, continuous monitoring of service levels against contractual KPIs, tracking of audit findings and remediation progress, and incident notification monitoring.

5. Exit testing: Financial entities must annually test their exit plans for critical ICT service providers through tabletop exercises and, at least every 3 years, operational exit drills.

6. Documentation retention: All due diligence records, assessments, and monitoring documentation must be retained for a minimum of 5 years.
obligations: Conduct documented pre-contracting risk assessment for all ICT arrangements supporting critical or important functions
Assess provider ICT security posture, certifications, BCP/DR capabilities, subcontracting chain, financial stability and regulatory standing before contracting
Apply proportionate due diligence: enhanced for critical functions, standard for non-critical arrangements
Assess concentration risk (Art.29) before contracting with providers already serving multiple financial entities
Conduct annual formal performance and security reviews for all providers supporting critical or important functions
Monitor service levels continuously against contractual KPIs and track audit finding remediation
Test exit plans via tabletop exercises annually and operational drills at least every 3 years
Retain all due diligence records, assessments, contracts and monitoring documentation for minimum 5 years
Include all critical and important function ICT providers in the Register of Information (Art.28(3))
Report concentration risk findings to the management body and competent authority when thresholds are exceeded

articles.title: RTS/ITS on Register of Information — Content, Format and Reporting
articles.text:
The EBA Implementing Technical Standards on the Register of Information (RoI) under DORA Article 28(3) establish the mandatory format and content requirements for the ICT third-party service provider register that financial entities must maintain and submit to competent authorities. The RoI follows the EBA Master Template structure:

1. RT.01.01 — General Overview: One row per financial entity reporting. Contains: LEI code, entity name, competent authority, reporting period, total number of ICT third-party service providers, number of providers supporting critical or important functions.

2. RT.02.01 — ICT Third-Party Service Providers: One row per ICT provider arrangement. Contains: provider name, provider LEI (if applicable), country of establishment, provider type (cloud, software, data, network, other), start and end dates of arrangement, service description, criticality classification (critical, important, standard), vendor status (active, under review, exited), ICT function categories supported, next review date, and exit strategy reference.

3. RT.03.01 — Contractual Arrangements: One row per contract. Contains: contract reference, signing date, governing law jurisdiction, notice periods for termination, SLA metrics committed, audit rights provisions, and data location commitments.

4. RT.04.01 — Certifications: One row per certification per provider. Contains: certification type (ISO 27001, SOC 2, CSA-STAR, ISO 22301), issuing body, certification date, expiry date, and current status (valid, expiring-soon, expired).

5. RT.05.01 — Cloud Services: One row per cloud arrangement. Contains: cloud service model (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS), deployment model (public, private, hybrid), data processing regions, and multi-cloud strategy details.

6. Submission frequency: The RoI must be submitted to the competent authority at least annually and upon material changes. Competent authorities may request ad-hoc submissions at any time.

7. Data quality: Financial entities are responsible for the accuracy and completeness of all RoI data. Incorrect submissions may constitute a breach of DORA Article 28.
obligations: Maintain a complete Register of Information covering all ICT third-party service provider arrangements
Populate all five EBA Master Template sheets: RT.01.01, RT.02.01, RT.03.01, RT.04.01, RT.05.01
Include provider LEI codes, country of establishment, service type, and criticality classification for every provider
Record contract details including governing law, notice periods, SLA metrics, and audit rights
Track all provider certifications (ISO 27001, SOC 2, CSA-STAR, ISO 22301) with expiry dates and status
Document cloud services with service model, deployment model, and data processing regions
Submit the Register of Information to the competent authority at least annually
Update and resubmit the RoI upon any material change to ICT third-party arrangements
Ensure accuracy and completeness of all RoI data — inaccurate submissions may constitute a DORA breach
Retain the RoI and all supporting documentation for a minimum of 5 years
